qas.question: What coin, as of 1982, is now primarily made of zinc?
What is a concern with the new zinc pennies?
Ingesting zinc can cause lack of muscle movement and coordination called what?
Why have people reported zinc intoxication?
What coin as of 1983 is now only made of zinc?
What is a requirement with the new zinc pennies?
Why have people never reported zinc intoxication?
What did one reported case of ingestion of 4250 pennies result in?
What metal is no longer found in pennies?

context: In 1982, the US Mint began minting <a0_0><b4_0>pennies<b4_0/><a0_0/> coated in <b8_0>copper<b8_0/> but made primarily of zinc. With the new zinc pennies, there is the potential for <a1_0><b5_0>zinc toxicosis<b5_0/><a1_0/>, which can be fatal. One reported case of chronic ingestion of 425 pennies (over 1 kg of zinc) resulted in death due to gastrointestinal bacterial and fungal sepsis, whereas another patient, who ingested 12 grams of zinc, only showed <b7_0>lethargy and <a2_0>ataxia<b7_0/><a2_0/> (gross lack of coordination of muscle movements). Several other cases have been reported of humans suffering zinc intoxication by the <a3_0><b6_0>ingestion of zinc coins<b6_0/><a3_0/>.
